clueweb22-en0006-90-11711.point_content: The Canaanites engaged in acts considered criminal, and God waited over 400 years before commanding they be driven out.
spans: We must first understand that the Canaanites engaged in acts that would be considered criminal in any civilized society–incest, infant sacrifice, ritual prostitution, bestiality. Also, God waited over 400 years for Canaan to hit moral rock-bottom before commanding they be driven out (Gen. 15:16).

clueweb22-en0006-90-11711.point_content: The language of 'utterly destroy' or 'leave alive nothing that breathes' is hyperbolic in Scripture’s war texts and should not be taken literally as complete annihilation.
spans: Second, the “utterly destroy” or “leave alive nothing that breathes” language is hyperbolic in Scripture’s war texts as in other ancient Near Eastern war texts. It typically stands alongside mention of many survivors—like when sports teams use the language of “totally slaughtering” their opponents.

clueweb22-en0006-90-11711.point_content: The historical narrative style of the Bible uses literary conventions and hyperbole, so passages where God commands violence may not be literal.
spans: Those passages occur in the context of a historical narrative. We are reading history, not as a 21 st century writer would write it, but history written by the literary conventions, style of narration and level of precision used by an the ancient Near Eastern writer.

Hagiographic hyperbole is a term used by philosopher Nicholas Wolterstorff to describe the kind of historical writing you see in the book of Joshua. The basic idea is that the accounts of Israel’s early battles in Canaan are narrated in a particular style, which is not intended to be literal in all of its details and contains a lot of hyperbole, formulaic language and literary expressions for rhetorical effect.

clueweb22-en0006-90-11711.point_content: The Bible contains a general rule against killing innocent people but allows for rare exceptions in cases of supreme emergency or greater good.
spans: There are (a) absolute duties to love God and avoid idolatry, (b) general duties that, all things being equal, ought to be obeyed such as “don’t deceive” and “don’t kill,” and (c) unusual cases of supreme emergency, in which some general duties may be overridden.
This means that while a loving and just God does endorse a general rule against killing the innocent, he could allow exceptions to it in rare, unusual occasions.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: The accusation that religion causes war is especially simplistic when applied to the pre-modern era.
spans: The accusation that religion causes war is especially simplistic when applied to the pre-modern era.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Religion, then, was not thought of as somehow separate from the rest of life and therefore could not be specifically identified as the cause of war.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: People groups, states and empires resorted to war for multiple reasons, including economic and social concerns.
spans: In reality, people groups, states and empires resorted to war for multiple reasons, including economic and social concerns.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Religion has sometimes helped reduce or even stop war.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Secular states have often been incredibly violent.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Religion has often acted as a corrective to state violence, with variations of the ‘do unto others what you would like others to do unto you’ golden rule.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: An essentially peaceful religion can become more violent and aggressive in its thinking when it is imbedded in a people who live in a climate of fear, violence and humiliation.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: The genocide in Rwanda involved complicity and active participation of Christian churches and personnel in the violence.
spans: A striking example of this is the genocide in Rwanda.
Timothy Longman notes the extensive criticism faced by that country’s Christian churches, not only for failing to oppose the genocide, but for complicity in the violence.

Longman’s research confirms these conclusions. He says church personnel and institutions ‘were actively involved in the programme of resistance to popular pressures for political reform that culminated in the 1994 genocide, and numerous priests, pastors, nuns, brothers, catechists, and Catholic and Protestant lay leaders supported, participated in, or helped to organize the killings.’

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Fear and terror can follow when the roots of faith do not reach fully into the depths of God’s love.
spans: When the roots of our faith do not reach down fully into the depths of God’s love, fear and terror can follow.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Violence carried out in the name of Islam arises out of a context with a long tail of imperialism, repression, and forced secularisation.
spans: Although no excuse can be made for the barbaric violence carried out by individuals in the name of Islam, it does arise out of a context with a long tail.
British, Russian and American imperialism, oil and forced secularisation have all exacted a terrible price on the people of the Middle East.
The religion of Islam was brutally repressed—in Iran by the Shah, Iraq by Saddam Hussein, Turkey by Ataturk, and Eqypt by Nasser.

clueweb22-en0044-27-02613.point_content: Disaffected young people may be drawn to violence due to racism, marginalisation, and persuasive religious leaders articulating their plight.
spans: The racism and ghettoization of Islamic people in France has been identified by many as a likely contextual factor that could lead disaffected young people toward the kind of violence that is now emerging there.

Islamic religious leaders that appear to articulate the reasons for their plight, a way of striking back, a cause to die for, a reason to live, and a people to belong to can be persuasive to young people, who have a palpable sense of being discriminated against.

clueweb22-en0031-98-01669.point_content: The literature points in both directions, and there’s little reason to believe that there’s something unique to religious ideologies that cause them to foster violence.
spans: Overall, Wright and Khoo argue that the literature points in both directions, and that there’s little reason, at this relatively early juncture in understanding the connection between religion and behaviour, to believe that there’s something unique to religious ideologies that cause them to foster violence.

clueweb22-en0031-98-01669.point_content: Some studies show religion linked to increased violence, such as endorsement of nuclear and biological weapons after 9/11 and prejudice among Christians towards Jews.

“The more Christians perceive Jews as desecrators of Christianity, the more prejudice they exhibit toward [them].”

clueweb22-en0031-98-01669.point_content: Other studies show religiosity associated with less violence, such as less self-reported vengeance with greater church attendance and less violent behavior in correctional system and Sweden.

religiosity was correlated with “lower self-reported acts of actual violent behavior over one’s lifetime,”

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Religion scholar Bart Ehrman explains that the ideas of eternal rewards and punishments are not found in the Old Testament or in the teachings of Jesus.
spans: Bart Ehrman says the ideas of eternal rewards and punishments aren't found in the Old Testament or in the teachings of Jesus.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Ancient Israelites and Jews did not believe in the separation of soul and body, and the soul did not exist apart from the body.
spans: ancient Israelites and then Jews and then Jesus himself and his followers have a very different understanding of what the relationship between what we call body and soul.

Our view is that we - you've got two things going on in the human parts. So you have your body, your physical being, and you have your soul, this invisible part of you that lives on after death, that you can separate the two and they can exist - the soul can exist outside of the body. That is not a view that was held by ancient Israelites and then Jews, and it's not even taught in the Old Testament.
In the Old Testament, what we would call the soul is really more like what we would call the breath.
In the Old Testament, there's no idea that your soul goes one place or another because the soul doesn't exist apart from the body.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: The concept of heaven and hell as places of eternal reward and punishment developed later, influenced by Greek thought and the writings of Paul.
spans: It's not an accident that that came into Christianity after the majority of people coming into the Christian church were raised in Greek circles rather than in Jewish circles because in Jewish circles, there is no separation of the soul and the body.
The soul was immortal and would live forever in Greek thinking.
Paul is very important for understanding the history of heaven and hell, as he's important for understanding most things about early Christian thinking.
Paul came up with the idea that he would have a temporary residence up with Christ in God's realm, in heaven, until the end came.

This is what the later Paul has to say, and this is the beginning of the Christian idea of heaven and hell, that you can exist - even though your physical remains are dead, you can exist in the presence of God in heaven.
And once Paul started saying that, his followers really latched onto it because most of Paul's converts were from Greek circles.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: The idea of hell as a place of eternal punishment developed from the belief in the soul's immortality and Greek philosophical ideas.
spans: Well, so since these people believed that the soul was immortal, that you can kill the body but you can't kill the soul, they thought, well, OK, so our soul will go to heaven to be with God, but then they realized, well, what about the people who are not on the side of God?
And that's how you start getting the development of the idea of hell, that it's a place where souls go to be punished in - as the opposite of the people who go to heaven to be rewarded.
And in thinking this, as it turns out, the Christians are simply picking up on views that had been around among the Greeks since way back in the time of Plato.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Jesus and early Jewish thought did not teach the soul's immortality or eternal punishment; rather, they believed in resurrection at the end of time and annihilation of the wicked.
spans: Jesus isn't talking about heaven because he doesn't believe - he's a Jew - he doesn't believe in the separation of soul and body.
He doesn't think the soul is going to live on in heaven.
He thinks that there's going to be a resurrection of the dead at the end of time.
Jesus taught that the kingdom of God, this new physical place, was coming soon, and those who did not get into the kingdom were going to be annihilated.
Jesus believed that people would be destroyed when - at the end of time, they'd be annihilated.
Their punishment is they would not get the kingdom of God.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: The Book of Revelation's imagery of hell is often misunderstood; it describes the final judgment and destruction of evil forces, not eternal torment of human souls.
spans: I have to deal with this in my book, where I try to show that, in fact, the Book of Revelation does not describe eternal torment for sinners in the lake of fire.
The people, in the Book of Revelation, human beings who aren't on the side of God, are actually destroyed.
This is the view that is fairly consistent throughout the New Testament, starting with Jesus.
The book is all about the terrible destruction that is going to take place on Earth when God destroys everything that is opposed to him, before bringing in a good kingdom.

This, though, is not a book that describes what's going to happen to individuals when they die and go to heaven or hell; it's a description of the final judgment of God that somehow is going to be coming to Earth.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: The Old Testament explains plagues and pandemics as punishments from God for sin, but later Jewish thought introduced the idea of evil forces causing suffering.
spans: The old testament has a fairly uniform and rather stark explanation for why there are plagues or epidemics or pandemics.
In virtually every case, we're told that it's because God is punishing people.

Eventually, Jewish thinkers began to reason that it didn't make much sense because there were times when they would be doing what God told them to do, or at least they'd be doing their level best to do what God told them to do, and they'd still be suffering these plagues.
And that's when they developed the idea that, in fact, it's the forces of evil causing these disasters.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Highly religious views attributing pandemics to supernatural causes can be socially dangerous if they lead to rejecting scientific solutions.
spans: I think that sometimes those very highly religious views can be socially extremely dangerous because if you think that the cause is supernatural, then you don't have much motivation to find a natural solution.
It is quite dangerous to refuse the findings of science because of your personal beliefs.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Belief in hell can cause psychological harm and fear, while belief in heaven can provide hope and comfort.
spans: I will never try to talk somebody out of a belief in heaven, but I certainly will try to talk people out of a belief in hell because it's simply wrong, and it's harmful.
It has terrified people.
There are people who are terrified of dying because they're afraid - they are literally afraid that they will be tormented for trillions of years, just as the beginning.
I think that, in fact, it imposes emotional damage.

When people need to find life pleasant and hopeful and they need to be helpful to other people, they need to enjoy life, if all you're looking forward to is what's going to happen after you die, you can't really fully enjoy life now because this is just a dress rehearsal.

clueweb22-en0020-41-05811.point_content: Bart Ehrman does not believe religion causes war, but he notes that belief in heaven and hell has done both good and harm, including terrifying people.
spans: And of course, belief in heaven and hell has done a lot of good; it's also done a lot of harm.
